Logistics Planning For a Northern Pipeline
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The total cost of a large-diameter pipeline constructed from northern Alaska through the Mackenzie River Valley into Alberta will be in the order of two billion dollars. Material and labour are the major cost components, butit is not difficult to determine that about 10 per cent of the project cost is represented by material transportation. This 200-million-dollar item will be shared by all modes of transport, principally rail, truck and barge and, to a lesser degree, air.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>Advance logistics planning is required to ensure (a) informed and co-ordinated effort of the various modal participants and (b) efficient, accurate and timely movement of the many material items through the complex transportation matrix.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>Planning must pay due regard to (a) multiple origins with varying material purchase prices, (b) multiple destinations with varying quantity requirements, and (c) seasonal availability and seasonal capacity fluctuations of the various transportation elements in the network.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>A linear program model is being developed to facilitate decision-making in material and transportation purchasing, and thereby optimize the total delivered cost of all materials to the right-or-way.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>IT IS GENERALLY ACCEPTED that solution gas from Prudhoe Bay will be moved to U.S. markets by pipeline through the Mackenzie River Valley, and three major proposals have been advanced covering construction of such a line. Since September 1970, CN has been studying the logistics requirements of one of these proposals - that initiated by Alberta Gas Trunk Line - and this paper outlines the company's experience to date in planning for the transportation of equipment and materials required to construct and maintain the line.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>The Pipeline Proposal</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>A.G.T.L.'s proposal includes 1,550 miles of 48-in. line, extending from northwestern Alberta down the Mackenzie River Valley and across the Yukon and Alaska to Prudhoe Bay (Figure 1). Construction willextend over approximately 21/2 years, with most work being done during the winter months.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The approximate cost of the proposed line is $2.0 billion and, depending on where one starts to detail component costs, transportation can account for 7–10 per cent of the total cost. The necessity for, and financial implications of, good logistics planning are obvious.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Stockpiles</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>Stockpile sites have been tentatively designated along the pipeline route, but they are subject to change due to pipeline route revisions, new road construction or new delivery methods. Logistics planning incorporates the cost of stockpiling along with other transportation costs and forces early consideration of site selection, site preparation and assignment of proper equipment - cranes, forklifts, etc.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Study Objectives and Approach</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>The prime study objective has been to:formulate a plan which can optimize the movement of a variety of materials from many origins to many destinations.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Other objectives have been to:identify transportation alternatives which may be used to meet emergent situations;plan for the efficient co-ordination of participating carriers in a very major multi-modal operation;identify and work within ecological constraints;identify and quantify transportation equipment and ancillary facility needs and lead times required to obtain same.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

Three Recent Experiences in Open Office Planning
container-title: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
items.abstract: <jats:p>Theoretical considerations have led to the design and completion of three acoustically successful open-plan offices. With but minor compromises, each was treated with highly absorptive materials to reduce and to localize the sounds of speech and other activities. In two of the three cases, a steady level of background noise is generated and distributed electronically. Partial-height barriers are employed to maximize privacy between work stations. This paper briefly reviews the acoustical principles employed, methods adopted, and results achieved. Specifically, it deals with the questions of surface absorptivity and background noise. The findings include observations on the level and uniformity of background noise, the level of activity sounds, sound attenuation with distance, and barrier performance. While there has been no opportunity to collect and tabulate occupant response, the over-all results are very encouraging. They largely substantiate the validity of the approach taken and reinforce the value of exact acoustical design.</jats:p>

title: WATER SUPPLY PLANNING IN TEXAS
items.abstract: <jats:p>Because of unusual physical problems, peculiar to the state of Texas, and the rapid depletion of ground‐water resources, the Texas Water Plan was formulated in an effort to meet future water needs in that state.</jats:p>

Why Do Family Planning Patients Drop Out?
items.abstract: <jats:p>In a sample of 165 FPA patients, 67% had stopped attending the clinic after 3 years. Half the loss could be accounted for by transfers, moves and ceasing to need contraception. The drop-out rate was not related to age, social class or number of children. Of the three methods generally pre scribed, the greatest attrition occurred amongst the cap patients. In a sample of twenty-seven LA patients, 48% had dropped out.</jats:p>

An Operational Approach to Development Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p> After gaining virtually worldwide acceptance, questions are being raised about the usefulness of planning in accelerating the rate of development. Part of the problem with conventional planning is methodologic and part of it is based on the inadequacy of data; but the greatest part of the problem is that conventional planning is based on wrong assumptions about the environment in which plans must be implemented. After discussing the shortcomings of conventional planning, the author proposes another approach involving “planning from the bottom up” which includes annual plans, improved budgets, and multi-annual sector programs. After testing the new approach in countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America, the author concludes that this approach is more promising than the conventional one. </jats:p>

A Note on the Bergstrom-Smith Multi-Item Production Planning Model
items.abstract: <jats:p> This note demonstrates that the model proposed by Bergstrom and Smith (B & S) for deterministic multi-item production planning can, with some reinterpretation, be used to solve two related stochastic multi-item production planning problems. Specifically, the benefits of individual item-by-item treatment and diminishing marginal revenue contained in the B & S model can be obtained when future sales are (i) stochastic and uncontrollable, or (ii) stochastic but with the mean value under the control of the firm. We demonstrate that under both of these situations the certainty-equivalence property holds, thereby reducing the two stochastic problems to two related deterministic problems. </jats:p>

title: Housing and Town and Country Planning in India—Recent Trends and Development
Introduction to the Analysis of Development and Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p> Underdevelopment may be characterized in numerous ways, according to the vantage point from which it is analyzed. Social, political, cultural, and demographic elements may all be taken into account. When underdevelopment is analyzed from an economic point of view emphasis is given to the phenomenon of low availability of goods and services for the satisfaction of the needs and aspirations of the population. In this paper underdevelopment will be analyzed from the point of view of an economic planner. Integration of health services planning into the total development plan will also be discussed. Although this paper is only an introductory synthesis to a vast subject, it is believed that it may be of help to other specialists, particularly those whose efforts are directed towards raising the level of health and improving sanitary conditions. </jats:p>

A Group Process Model for Problem Identification and Program Planning
container-title: The Journal of Applied Behavioral Science
items.abstract: <jats:p> This article sets forth a group process approach useful for practicing administrators charged with a program development task. More specifically, meeting formats are suggested for involving the following critical reference groups in successive phases of program development: (1) clients (consumers or users) and first-line staff, in problem exploration; (2) external resource people and internal specialists, in knowledge exploration; (3) key administrators and resource controllers, in priority development and local adaptation; (4) organizational staff, in program proposal building; and (5) all constituencies, in final approval and evaluation designs. The meeting formats were suggested by contemporary small-group theory; the sequencing of the involvement of reference groups came from studies of community planning. </jats:p>

title: COMMERCIAL EGG PRODUCTION: A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF SOME OPERATIONAL AND STRUCTURAL PLANNING ALTERNATIVES
container-title: Canadian Journal of Agricultural Economics/Revue canadienne d'agroeconomie
items.abstract: <jats:p>This study compares a number of operational and structural planning alternatives using a simulation procedure. The objective is to demonstrate that the economic and physical disadvantages of oll‐in, all‐out replacement of laying birds can be significantly reduced by planning a laying operation so as to (a) ensure high rate of utilization of rearing and laying house capacities, (b) maintain a uniform flow of eggs to the market, (c) allow for the retention of laying birds beyond the normal duration of the laying cycle, (d) reduce “bottlenecks” in the flow of birds through the operation, and (e) reduce the importance of the in‐lay period in planning decisions. Four alternative plans were simulated over a ten‐year period. It was concluded that a commercial laying operation could be planned to meet stated objectives without having an adverse effect on the producer's net income position. It was also concluded that the “continuous” phasing of production through rearing and laying stages which results in an even flow of eggs to market could, if followed by producers, have a beneficial effect on egg prices to producers and might also alleviate some of the excess capacity problems of some poultry supply industries.</jats:p><jats:p>Cette dissertation présente la méthodologie, le modéle et les résultats ďune analyse économique comparant quelques alternatives de program‐mation fonctionnelles et structurales aux méthodes traditionnelles de rem‐placement discontinu dans la production commerciale des oeufs.</jats:p><jats:p>Une méthode mixte (stochastique‐déterministe) de simulation est employée afin ďy comparer un nombre ďalternatives de programmation utilisant les remplacements annuels et bi‐annuels. Les résultats révélent que les désavantages économique du remplacement discontinu peuuent être notablement réduits sans effets défavorables au niveau des revenus du producteur.</jats:p><jats:p>Il y est également question des implications étendues de cette production continue des oeufs en ce qu'elle pourrait provoquer des changements dans le cycle de prix des oeufs, ainsi que les changements structuraux a ľintérieur de certaines industries ďapprovisionnement.</jats:p>
